title: Do game developers play their own completed games? - Quora

response.answer_text: Generally, they do. They also play other games. There might be some backend programmers that do stuff in an engine that is not really related to gameplay who might not have to play the game. Think of network stuff and graphics algorithms as an example. But usually they have a passion for games and play the game anyways. The playing a developer does is very different from what you might think it is. If you work on something, you could spend hours playing just one little thing over and over until you get it just right. This is not the fun casual playthrough you do as a consumer. This is actual work where you focus on the details you work on, not your character progress or finishing a quest. Many game developers play other games. Sometimes for inspiration or to see what the competition does, most the time for fun. Those guys are passionate gamers, but playing their own game is work so they play something different to unwind. If you follow some dev blogs, you might see them mention the games they play from time to time. So if you want to become a game developer because it is playing computer games all day, you are kind of mislead. It is actually work and has little to do with how you play the game. It is the same as liking to drive fast cars and deciding to become a mechanic. While both needs a passion for cars, they are vastly different. And taking out the customers car for a joyride may get you fired from your job as a mechanic. The same may happen to you if you are game developer who just plays the game instead of doing actual work. Even the playing a QA tester for a game company or a pro gamer does is not the casual fun thing you might think it is. There is a lot of doing the same weird thing again and again until you are sick of it until you got it just right or found the weird little issue, even the grindiest of grind games are not that repetitive.

It is pointless for heavily story-based games, especially ones with bad repetitive gameplay (I think playing such games is pointless for anyone who values their time, but this is another story). It is also pointless for games based on solving static puzzles, as you already know all the solutions. But the situation is different for games based on skill and/or improvisation. Roguelikes in particular are often created because the developer wanted to play games like this, and see how the various elements interact together in a game. I play my games a lot during development to check that the game is challenging and the balance is right; after this, I feel that I have won, so I do not play that much myself. I play the harder challenges, to make sure that they are still possible. Improvisation is still interesting, but I rather prefer reading the players’ posts about the strategies they have devised, and comparing them to my own. Sometimes players devise their own challenges (“Is it possible to […]?”, or they get high scores in the leaderboards) and I try to beat these. I also like to play multiplayer, as this is a fresh experience. On the other hand — it could be said that roguelike developers do not play their own completed games, because roguelikes are never completed… they tend to get significant updates years after the “original” release.

Playing is really strongly encouraged by everyone in management. But… it’s awful. Take ThudGame. This was a multiplayer lobby, with 2-player-plus-observers board games. If I went into the lobby, I’d be challenged to a game. That was an hour of my time eaten up, that I couldn’t work on coding it. It was a fun game, and I might see some bugs that I otherwise wouldn’t, but I’d be better off working on the bugs I already knew about, or working on the next version. Take Furcadia. I initially joined the game as a player, volunteered as a newbie-welcomer, and was quickly stolen as a bug-tester, then offered a job as a developer, and eventually became the lead dev, and then the only dev. Each extra level of responsibility was accompanied by a corresponding reduction of my available time, and of my desire to go onto the game. I was in the game to socialise, you see. So I had a few choices. Socialize with people who knew me, but have to remember that I always had my “badge” on even if it was turned off, always had to be on my best behavior, always had to listen to people’s problems, and that everyone would be able to see me online and ask me for help.Get a new account and don’t tell anyone. I am insanely bad at “alting”, though - everyone who knows me even slightly can tell that I am me in about a minute of conversation.Get a new account, and build new friendships, never contacting old friends. This had no interest to me.So we observed this in each volunteer as they got more responsibility: they moved away from the game, spent more time in staff-only areas, or in the Skype chatrooms (I think they since moved to Discord, but same thing). Becoming a “public figure” makes you no longer want to go out in public.

I think it largely depends on the type of game and how well development on it went. For a story-driven single-player game that doesn't have a ton of replay value (a point-and-click adventure or puzzle game, for instance), no, probably not. Most developers would have been exposed to most or all of the game during development - maybe you'd blow through the completed version once to see how it came together, but you probably wouldn't see them playing it over and over by choice. If it's highly replayable (like the main focus is grinding for high scores/building your skill, or there is a large PvP component, or it's a sandbox game, or the game is a live service that is in constant development and adds new content all the time), maybe. Depends on how burned out you got during the game’s development, IMO. Maybe also how much your role involved painstakingly recreating bugs by hand. For example, I know a few people at Riot and they are all avid League Of Legends players. (I see some of them on Overwatch a lot too. Don't tell their bosses.) Game testers, on the other hand, I can see getting completely burned out on the games they play all day.

Absolutely. Most game developers work in the industry and/or stay in the industry because they love video games. They may love it in different ways from typical gamers but it’s hard to continue in the industry without a passion for them. Having a passion for them, they will typically play at least some video games. Many developers, being professionals with challenging jobs and long hours, might not play video games to the degree gamers will, but I’d venture to say the majority of developers will play at least something, at least once in awhile. If nothing else, staying up to date and having first hand knowledge of the gaming market is a tremendous advantage in the industry. You can’t really make things if you’re completely ignorant about the general trends at large, at least how it relates to your specific role. In this sense, a lot of games played by developers also double as research and developers often play games they have little personal interest in playing out of professional curiosity.

If you’re asking if I spend thousands of hours playing the in-progress product, usually in testmaps, the answer is “yes.” If you’re asking whether or not I play through the finished product and experience the story, etc. as the average player would, the answer is typically “no.” You may be one of those people who enjoys playing single-player action/adventure games for example. Your typical playtime in those games is probably on the order of low tens of hours to maybe a hundred or so, at best. Now imagine having played that game, in some premature yet representative form, for an average of 2 hours per day, for the last 2–5 years. Not just more than the average player, but perhaps hundreds of times more. It changes your outlook a bit. I have played through some of the games I worked on, but not most of them. It’s no knock against the games I worked on - really I have been fortunate to have worked on mostly-successful, mostly-shipping games - but it’s still different working on them than consuming them as an average player.

It depends on the game. Most of my game dev experience is in QA (and yes, QA counts as game development), and I would say about 75% of the games I’ve tested I never want to look at again. This is a fairly common mindset among QA testers; in fact, it was one of the things I was warned about when I first started in QA. Think about it: if you spent 8+ hours a day, 5+ days a week, playing the same game over and over again—in various states of brokenness—and then, when it was released, you had the opportunity to play that game again…what are the chances that you’d take that opportunity? Even if it was perfect and all the bugs were fixed (hahahaha like that ever happens)? Probably pretty low. However, there are some exceptions. I’ve been lucky enough to work on some games that are so good that I would happily play them again, even though I know them inside and out. Yakuza 2, for instance, and The Blackwell Epiphany. Also, there are some online games I’ve tested (mostly MMOs) that I wouldn’t mind playing again; the nice thing about MMOs is that it’s practically impossible for a single person to see everything in them, so the “been there, done that” feeling isn’t as strong. Plus, playing with other people adds a dimension to the game that you don’t get to experience during the QA cycle. The sad thing about working in game dev is that you usually get a free copy of the game you worked on when it comes out, and for the reasons I outlined above, it might just end up gathering dust on your shelf. Such a waste!

It depends on the game and the developer. As a game programmer, I played the game I was developing hundreds of times, but usually just to check or playtest the feature I was working on. I didn’t play it all the way through that often, though I would a few times, especially near the end of development. After the game was released, I didn’t play it again, except maybe to show it off to people.  I programmed the UI for these menus, as well as a ton of the rest of the game. I inserted a cheat here so the program would automatically select some players and start a game without me having to set up a game every time. Does it look good? After seeing it 100,000 times, I can’t tell anymore. (image credit) If I had developed a game in a genre I was really into, I might’ve played it after it was completed, especially if it had some random elements so it would keep me interested. For example, I can see myself playing Diablo after it came out if I had helped develop it. But it all really depends. Playing a game over and over and over when it isn’t completed can really take the fun out of the game, even when it’s done.

Once someone has started working in game development they no longer enjoy games the same way. They tend to pick up a lot of the decisions that the development team did. They essentially are taking the game apart, trying to figure out how they developers did it, trying to get a “why” behind certain technical choices. Bugs, or shortcuts/approximations jump at them. They also tend to play (subconsciously) like testers, trying to break the game. I have quit the videogame industry for more than 15 years and I still can’t shut this down. Conversely, solving certain technical challenges in game development can bring a satisfaction similar to solving a puzzle or a quest in a game. In most games, including some not very ambitious projects, there is something that no one else has ever done and being the first that figures out how to do that is very stimulating. A lot of game developers or people in the game business more generally are very interested in the pop culture aspect of games (and adjacent domains like sci-fi, toys, fantasy, movies, animes, board games, comics, history, etc.), partly because they enjoy it and feel they belong in it but also because part of their mind is always trying to think of future projects and combining ideas. So, I feel the vast majority of game developers are very interested in the technical/artistic aspects of game development but not that many are gamers in the first sense. Some developers are very candid and will just claim that they don’t play games. And those who do play games do it a bit differently than their audience.

I played all the games I worked on. Once the game was released, the company gave you a copy for free, so… why not? I wasn’t part of QA, I didn’t play the unfinished game extensively to the point I don't want to touch it. So I played the game. It was fun. As for the live game I’m currently working on, the team regularly schedules playtests, so I play it all the time.

upvoters.user_id: Justin Mishina 三品 亮司

response.answer_text: Mostly not so much, especially while they’re still fresh. The reason being that we mostly play them about 100x as much as any other user would when we’re developing and testing them. Sometimes, going back and playing old games for nostalgia purposes is fun.

Yes. I play a lot. Not necceserally only the games of the genre i'm helping develop, since i understand that i'm somewhat more of a niche player, but i do play and am able to enjoy games, likely in a way that is different than the way that my kids, for example, enjoy the games they play. When i like a game a lot, i often can't avoid “striping” it to its design layers: mechanics, balance, aesthetics, trying to realize ehy certain choices were made. I also often can't avoid trying to “solve” the game by understsnding the design choices the creators had to choose from, and how they “wanted” me to play their game. I do enjoy the games still, despite this forced analytical process, but it is a different type of fun, i guess. However, it doesn't completely replace the “usual” casual fun i derive from a game. Often times, especially when a game is new to me or when the genre is far from those i've worked on, i am too immersed in the gameplay and enjoy it in s way that is probably more similar to the way a “standard” gamer does.

I guess this kind of depends on what sort of work you’re doing on developing the game. For example, I have a friend who works at Blizzard, in their art department. He is also a very avid player of their games, and I constantly see him online playing Overwatch regularly. However, he’s one of hundreds of employees there. He does not build the game from the ground up, and instead plays a very small role in the overall development of the game. I imagine the answer would be different if you were developing a game on your own, or as part of a very small indie development team.

Maybe once or twice in it'd completed state, but I don't think it's that fun when you made the game and you know everything that happens. While making games, we have to constantly test. You change one line if code trying to get a little feature perfect, you play through a part of the game. It wasn't quite right? Change it and try again. Often you test games thousands of times during development. So in a way, we already have played our games many many times.

It’s funny but in a lot of cases game developers do not play their games following release just due to time and moving onto new projects, which requires you to adjust your mindset when you’re a professional creative. Back in the day, when it was just console and PC games, our dev cycles were so long you’d work on a game day in day out for 2–5 years and over time it stopped becoming a game. Those are the hardest to play afterwards, every step is a painful reminder of the time invested. Nowadays it’s a bit different. Dev cycles are much shorter thanks to the tools and platforms and games require a lot more post-release work to survive and thrive. So now it’s more of a requirement than something we want to do, we have to stay on top of the user base, the games meta and find new bugs that are stopping our games from earning.

Personally, for the only game I’ve made, yes, a lot! In fact, the only reason for me to make that game is because I wanted an actually good game on my iOS tablet, and when I didn’t find it (this was before Hearthstone was released), I set out to make one. It was a skill-based action game (with same-device multiplayer and “vs AI” singleplayer), so it’s not like I was already tired from the story or anything ;)

Between the time demands of work, the desire and expectation to improve yourself through personal projects, and the general demands of being an adult, we collectively don’t play nearly as many games as we’d like to. But yes, virtually everyone who works in the industry in a fan of video games. And a large percentage of us are also into board games and tabletop role playing games.

Basically, I like to return to one of my projects from time to time, but only after long time since release (one year / 1.5 years). No 100% completion, just few minutes. The reason is simple: we, developers, have enough looking on the same title, graphics and levels layout after months or even years of tough working. We are fed up. No idea is it true for developers working at commercial titles, here you have an “indie” point of view. Jason

Yes we do, but the games we’re working on are definitely not enjoyable as games on the market. As an indie game developer, playing these games is like the actual work - you are testing your games, and you want to fix it if you find anything worth improving. And to be honest, I don’t think anybody likes working. On the other hand, if your games are published and you move on to the next project, and you probably will never touch them again, your games become something like your own creation, and something belongs to your own past. They become adorable again - and who knows, you might be able to really enjoy them.

Yes. Game developers need to try there games after they updated the game or just made it. They need to check for bugs and mostly to feel proud of the game they made. So your answer is Yes. Game developers do play there own games. Even without a reason they play there games. Only stubborn game developers don’t, as they think the game has no bugs.

I don’t often make games that are reliant on a specific progression, so I will replay them. I have also developed a tabletop role playing game, and I play that a ton. They don’t get stale the same way a video game does. Even something like skyrim doesn’t have a candle on tabletop in that regard, and I have a particular emphasize on character creation being truly varied so that doesn’t get stale

Yes they do. They have to test their game to make sure it works and it doesn't crash. But some times game developers will have a few people to test their game that will send feedback to the game developers on any bugs.

Chef eat food. Not just cooking Artist enjoy artworks. Not just creating art. Writer read books. Not just writing all day long. Singer listen to music. Not just singing everyday. Game developer… . is playing. . ChainInspirationIsReal http://rechronicle.itch.io
As part of playtesting, yes they have to in order to make sure it works. As in playing a multiplayer game with the community, not necessarily.

We do a lot of play testing to ensure features are implemented but free , a benefit of using the agile methodology. Once the feature is implanted I play test it then so do the designers to fine tune the mechanic . Good for small projects bad for large ones
When it's finished, no. I prefer to watch others play it. I play it so much during development I get sick of it.
In terms of multiplayer games, yes, especially in genres I like. It’s fun to be part of the community.
